content: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="ISO-8859-1"?> <metadata> <idinfo> <datsetid>gov.noaa.nws.ohd.hdsc: OHD-HDSC-NOAAAtlas14V5v2011-PI-ch</datsetid> <citation> <citeinfo> <origin>NOAA/NWS/Office of Hydrologic Development, Hydrometeorological Design Studies Center</origin> <pubdate>20091218</pubdate> <title>Precipitation Frequency for Chuuk, Pacific Islands - NOAA Atlas 14 Volume 5</title> <geoform>raster digital data</geoform> <serinfo> <sername>NOAA Atlas 14</sername> <issue>Volume 5</issue> </serinfo> <pubinfo> <pubplace>Silver Spring, MD, USA</pubplace> <publish>NOAA/NWS/Office of Hydrologic Development, Hydrometeorological Design Studies Center</publish> </pubinfo> <onlink>http://hdsc.nws.noaa.gov/hdsc/pfds/pfds_gis.html</onlink> <onlink>http://hdsc.nws.noaa.gov/hdsc/pfds/</onlink> <onlink>http://www.nws.noaa.gov/ohd/hdsc/index.html</onlink> <onlink>ftp://hdsc.nws.noaa.gov/pub/hdsc/data/</onlink> </citeinfo> </citation> <descript> <abstract>This GIS grid atlas contains precipitation frequency estimates for the Pacific Islands that are based on precipitation data. This atlas is a new release from the NWS and does not update any other publication. The precipitation frequency grids are available for durations from 5 minutes through 60 days, and for average recurrence intervals of 1 year through 1,000 years. AMS and PDS results are provided; refer to published documentation for differences between the two.</abstract> <purpose>Precipitation frequency estimates are used as basic design criteria for a wide variety of hydraulic structures such as culverts, roadway drainages, bridges and small dams. This dataset is for the display and/or analyses of spatially distributed point precipitation frequency estimates.</purpose> <supplinf>none.</supplinf> </descript> <timeperd> <timeinfo> <rngdates> <begdate>191402</begdate> <enddate>200806</enddate> </rngdates> </timeinfo> <current>Climatological period from which the point precipitation observations were taken.</current> </timeperd> <status> consistency.</attraccr> </attracc> <logic>All data were based on precipitation-reporting stations that had at least 10 years of 15-minute, hourly and/or daily precipitation data. Similar quality assurance procedures were used with all input data sets.</logic> <complete>Observed point precipitation values originated from a variety of sources. Station data were subjected to quality control checks by the National Climatic Data Center (NCDC) or the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) and the Hydrometeorological Design Studies Center.</complete> </rngdates> </timeinfo> <srccurr>ground condition</srccurr> </srctime> <srccitea>NCDC Climate Data Online -Precipitation Data, Daily, http://gis.ncdc.noaa.gov/website/ims-cdo/preciphr/</srccitea> <srccontr>Location and values of known daily precipitation amounts.</srccontr> </srcinfo> <procstep> <procdesc>This spatial data set was prepared by spatially interpolating point precipitation frequency estimates. The precipitation frequency estimates were calculated using regional L-moment frequency approach based on an annual maximum series data. Annual maximum series bases estimates were converted to partial duration based frequency estimates. The spatial interpolation of the point precipitation frequency estimates was accomplished by first interpolating 1-day MAMs. The 1-day MAM grids were used to derive MAM grids for other durations using relationships in MAM ratios across durations. The MAM grids were then used to derive grids of precipitation frequency estimates by rescaling with corresponding regional growth factors for each recurrence interval and duration. For more details about the processes used to create this grid, please see the NOAA Atlas 14 Volume 5 documentation.</procdesc> <procdate>200912</procdate> </procstep> </lineage> </dataqual> <spdoinfo> <direct>Raster</direct> <rastinfo> <cvaltype>integer</cvaltype> <rasttype>Grid Cell</rasttype> <rowcount>31</rowcount> <colcount>31</colcount> <vrtcount>1</vrtcount> </rastinfo> </spdoinfo> <spref> <horizsys> <geograph> <latres>0.0100</latres> <longres>0.0100</longres> <geogunit>Decimal degrees</geogunit> </geograph> <geodetic> <horizdn>WGS 84</horizdn> <ellips>WGS 84</ellips> <semiaxis>6378135.000000</semiaxis> <denflat>298.260000</denflat> </geodetic> </horizsys> </spref> <eainfo> <detailed> <enttyp> <enttypl>precipitation frequency grid cell value</enttypl> <enttypd>ASCII integer</enttypd> <enttypds>Self-evident</enttypds> </enttyp> <attr> <attrlabl>precipitation frequency grid cell value</attrlabl> <attrdef>spatially gridded precipitation frequency estimates</attrdef> <attrdefs>NWS/OHD/HDSC</attrdefs> <attrdomv> <udom>Sequential unique whole numbers that are automatically generated.</udom> </attrdomv> </attr> <attr> <attrlabl>Value</attrlabl> <attrdef>Feature geometry. Grid cell precipitation in inches*1000</attrdef> <attrdefs>HDSC</attrdefs> <attrdomv> <udom>Coordinates defining the features.</udom> </attrdomv> <attrdomv> <rdom> <rdommin>0</rdommin> <rdommax>9999999</rdommax> <attrunit>1000ths of inches; -999 is missing</attrunit> </rdom> </attrdomv> <attrvai> <attrva>0.01</attrva> <attrvae>measurement accuracy of precipitation gauges in inches</attrvae> </attrvai> </attr> </detailed> </eainfo> <distinfo> <distrib> <cntinfo> <cntorgp> <cntorg>NOAA/National Weather Service, Office of Hydrologic Development, Hydrometeorological Design Studies Center</cntorg> <cntper>HDSC Questions</cntper> </cntorgp> <cntaddr> <addrtype>mailing and physical</addrtype> <address>1325 East-West Highway</address> <city>Silver Spring</city> <state>MD</state> <postal>20910</postal> </cntaddr> </cntinfo> </distrib> <resdesc>Downloadable data.</resdesc> <distliab>Users must assume responsibility to determine the appropriate use of these data.</distliab> <stdorder> <digform> <digtinfo> <formname>ASCII</formname> <transize>0.25</transize> </digtinfo> <digtopt> <onlinopt> <computer> <networka> <networkr>HDSC PFDS;</networkr> <networkr>a) for PDS-based estimates - chXyrYYaZ.ver3 (X = average recurrence interval; YY = duration; Z = null for precipitation frequency value, u for upper confidence limit, l for lower confidence limit); b) for AMS-based estimates - chXyrYYaZ_AMS.ver3 (X = 100/annual exceedance probability; YY = duration; Z = null for precipitation frequency value, u for upper confidence limit, l for lower confidence limit).</networkr> </networka> </computer> </onlinopt> </digtopt> </digform> <fees>none</fees> </stdorder> <techpreq>A grid-based GIS such as ArcInfo (GRID) or Arcview 3.x/8.x/9.x (with Spatial Analyst Extension).
